title: Multiple Six-Year Periods Reset

scenario_info.name: Multiple Six-Year Periods Reset
scenario_info.description: Rebecca purchases a home, lives in it for 5 years, rents it out for 4 years while working overseas, moves back in for 2 years, then rents it again for 5 years before selling. Because she genuinely moved back in and re-established the property as her main residence, she is entitled to a new 6-year period for the second rental. The full main residence exemption applies.
applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.145: Six-year absence rule can be reset
When owner genuinely moves back in and re-establishes main residence, a new 6-year period starts
9 years total rental split: 4 years + 5 years = both within respective 6-year limits
Key: Must genuinely re-establish main residence (not just a brief visit)

property_history.description: Genuinely re-established as main residence - 6-year clock resets

properties.notes: Full main residence exemption. First rental (4 years) covered by first 6-year period. Genuine move-back reset the clock. Second rental (5 years) covered by new 6-year period.

user_query: I rented my home for 4 years, moved back in for 2 years, then rented it again for 5 years before selling. That's 9 years of rental total. Is my six-year rule exceeded?
